awd_titl_txt: Promoting the Self-Regulated Use of Effective Learning Strategies in Gateway Undergraduate STEM Courses
awd_abstract_narration:
Under the sponsorship of Dr. Uma Tauber at Texas Christian University and Dr. Mark McDaniel at Washington University at St. Louis, this postdoctoral fellowship award supports an early-career scientist investigating the effectiveness of a multicomponent strategy-training intervention on college student learning in Chemistry and Biology courses. The proposed research promises to have a far-reaching impact on student achievement and science by providing students with the tools necessary to overcome the barriers to using effective learning strategies and mastering course concepts when studying on their own. Because departure from science is particularly high among women, ethnic/racial minorities, and first-generation college students, the strategy-training intervention is expected to have the greatest benefit for students from underrepresented groups.

Many students enter college with insufficient awareness of effective learning strategies and struggle to adopt strategies that promote long-term retention and understanding of content, which leads them to earn low or non-passing grades in challenging science courses. Despite a multitude of research supporting the effectiveness of retrieval practice (i.e., recalling information from memory), self-explanation (i.e., explaining how to-be-learned information is related to already known information), and distributed practice (i.e., spreading study strategies out across time) for improving learning and achievement in the sciences, little research has focused on promoting students’ use of these strategies when studying on their own. The current research proposes a multicomponent strategy-training intervention to address four barriers that prevent students from using these effective strategies during their own learning: (1) lack of knowledge about the strategies and how to use them to master course concepts, (2) not believing the strategy is effective for lasting learning, (3) lack of motivation to exert the effort that these strategies require, and (4) poor management of study time. Specifically, the proposed research aims to answer the following questions: Does a strategy-training intervention informed by the Knowledge, Belief, Commitment, and Planning framework (McDaniel & Einstein, 2020) lead to greater use of effective learning strategies compared to a control group? If so, does this increased use of effective strategies lead to improvement on measures of course achievement and persistence in gateway undergraduate science courses? To answer these questions, two large-scale experiments will be conducted in two gateway undergraduate Chemistry and Biology courses to evaluate the effects of the strategy-training intervention on (a) student knowledge and beliefs about effective learning strategies, (b) students’ self-regulated learning behavior, (c) exam performance, and (d) persistence in science.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Research conducted at Texas Christian University explored the effectiveness of a multicomponent intervention designed to enhance college students' use of effective learning strategies. Two experiments evaluated the impacts on student beliefs, self-regulated learning behavior, and overall achievement in foundational science courses.

Experiment 1 took place in Fall 2023, targeting an Introductory Biology course with approximately 60 student participants. Participants were randomly assigned to either a strategy-training intervention or an active control group focused on healthy life habits. The strategy-training intervention focused on two effective learning strategies: elaboration (i.e., making meaningful connections by generating explanations, creating examples, or explaining how new information relates to known information) and retrieval practice (i.e., self-testing over to-be-learned material).

Experiment 2, conducted in Fall 2024 in a General Chemistry course with about 240 students, used a quasi-experimental design. Students in one section of the course experienced the strategy-training intervention while students in another section of the course experienced the healthy-life habits control intervention. The strategy-training intervention focused on retrieval practice and interleaving (i.e., mixing different kinds of problems or kinds of material within a single study session).

The strategy-training intervention took approximately two hours and involved dynamic discussions and activities that taught students when, why, and how to use effective learning strategies, included demonstrations of the consequences of using versus not using these strategies, encouraged reflection on their goals, and helped students create specific study plans for implementation. Students in the control group received instruction and activities focused on maintaining a balanced lifestyle.

Pretests and posttests assessed students' knowledge and beliefs about various learning strategies, web-based surveys tracked self-regulated learning behavior across the semester, and course exams served as measures of course achievement.

These were some of the main findings:

  • College chemistry and biology students enter college believing that a variety of learning strategies -- such as attending lecture, reading, self-testing, and spacing out their studying -- are effective for promoting retention and comprehension. These 
  • Students reported studying for their science course for an average of 4-7 hours per week, spaced across 4-5 days. Commonly reported strategies were (re)reading course materials and self-testing.
  • Students reported that the following factors influenced their study habits: upcoming course deadlines, amount of time available, their mood/mental health state, their current grade in the course, and other obligations (e.g., other coursework, sports, social activities).
  • Reports of self-regulated learning behavior and measures of course achievement (i.e., exam performance) did not significantly differ between students who received the strategy-training intervention and students who received a healthy life habit control intervention.

Overall, the results provide a dynamic picture of study behavior across a semester, and suggest that a light-touch intervention is likely insufficient in promoting meaningful changes in learning strategies. The findings from both experiments highlight the complexity of fostering effective learning strategies among college students. Future research should aim to develop and implement more comprehensive techniques that can support students in overcoming obstacles to effective learning, achievement, and persistence in science.
